Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Air-Sea Gas Exchange in High Winds for Improvement of Physics-Based Air-Sea Transfer Parameterizations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The parameterization of air-sea interaction at high wind speeds continues as a topic of great interest to air-sea exchange. Being able to predict air-sea gas exchange of radiatively important gases such as carbon dioxide is needed to project climate scenarios. A previous NSF award (AGS- 1036062; 1036006 Collaborative Research: Measuring Air-Sea Gas Exchange in High Winds for Improvement of Physics-Based Air-Sea Transfer Parameterizations: HiWinGS) funded a 4-year project to develop and improve gas exchange measurements. A HiWinGS cruise to the Labrador Sea was successfully completed in Oct-Nov 2013, yielding more than 700 hours of coordinated flux and wave physics observations, including more than 100 hours at wind speeds of 15-27 m/s. This is a unique data set.

Specific goals of the analysis work undertaken here are to:
1) present an analysis of the observed transfer coefficients for heat, momentum, the trace gases DMS and CO2 with respect to wind speed, stress, bubble plume characteristics and sea state;
2) further develop the refined physical representations for gas transfer at high wind speeds in available bulk flux algorithms; and
3) engage in a critical assessment of the various CO2 flux data sets obtained from the HiWinGS cruise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wind-generated mixing at the ocean surface (i.e., wave action) greatly enhances the rate of air-sea gas transfer through turbulent diffusion and bubble injection.  In general, the rate of gas transfer increases with increasing wind speed, and the gas transfer velocity is often modeled as a simple function of wind speed alone, but the wind speed dependence is not the same for all gases.  A model which treats the various physical mechanisms independently (i.e. a ‘universal’ physical model) can, in theory, represent the air-sea transfer of any gas species .  But we have an incomplete understanding of many important physical mechanisms, especially with respect to the details of  transfer enhancement by breaking waves and bubbles at high wind speeds.

Direct measurements of gas transfer enhancement at high wind speeds are challenging – laboratory studies in wave tanks do not fully represent conditions in the open ocean, and measurements at sea from ships and buoys are difficult.  The High Wind speed Gas exchange Study (HiWinGS) was conducted to develop improved methods for measuring trace gas fluxes from a ship and to deploy these methods, together with a suite of wave and bubble measurements, on a dedicated research cruise under high wind speed conditions with large waves.

Initial work by HiWinGS participants focused on developing an improved method of measuring air-sea CO2 flux using recently developed cavity ring-down gas analyzer technology (CRDS).  The CRDS eliminates some of the interferences and limitations affecting other CO2 flux analyzers, resulting in significantly improved flux detection limits (Figure 1).  Development work by HiWinGS collaborators in the UK focused on new and novel instruments to measure wave spectra and bubble size distrubutions in the surface ocean under high wind conditions.  The HiWinGS cruise represents the first time these new methods have been used in a dedicated gas transfer field program.

The field experiment was conducted in fall 2013 in the Labrador Sea, a location known for frequent storms and as an important sink for atmospheric CO2.  We encountered seven storm events at locations east of Labrador and south of Nova Scotia (Figure 2).

Comparing the gas transfer velocities for CO2 and dimethylsulfide (DMS), we see much less enhancement of DMS transfer with increasing wind speed.  This is the expected behavior for a more soluble gas that is less influenced by breaking waves and bubbles (Figure 3).  We also observe a tendency for the CO2 transfer to increase under a constant wind speed as waves grow larger and the sea state approaches equilibrium conditions.  The DMS transfer velocity does not show this tendency as much.  This is also consistent with the solubility difference in these two gases.

Previous studies suggested that sea state-dependent gas transfer models should be superior to wind-speed-only formulas.  We examined several empirical gas transfer models with various wave dependencies and conclude that a Reynolds number parameter incorporating friction velocity (wind) and wave height is marginally superior to the wind-speed-only model.  A physical gas transfer model (COAREG) incorporating the Reynolds number parameter reproduces the mean trend in transfer velocity with wind speed for both DMS and CO2, but fails to provide a significant improvement in mean squared error compared to the emiprical wind speed model.  We conclude the Reynolds parameter may not adequately capture the relevant sea state dependency.  It may also be overly optimistic to expect a large decrease in mean squared error since other sources of additional random error (sampling error, etc.) may be much larger than variance related to sea state.  Our continuing work will focus on improvements to the physical model.

Two previous field programs observed a decrease in gas transfer rate in the presence of large waves, but we do not see evidence for this during HiWinGS (Figure 4).  The HiWinGS measurements include observations in the presence of very large waves (up to 8m wave height), so this discrepancy between programs does not appear to be related to sea state.  The contrast with earlier observations remains a mystery.  Biologically-derived soluble surfactants in the ocean are known to reduce gas transfer.  Due to location and season, HiWinGS may be much less affected by surfactants compared to other cruises and this may explain the transfer suppression observed in previous field studies.  This question can possibly be resolved in a future study where surfactant measurements are included.

The HiWinGS project is the most successful field program to-date examining gas exchange in high wind conditions.  The observations are consistent with our understanding of the solubility-dependence of gas transfer and provide important insight into sea state dependence.  The observations will be useful for continued development of advanced physical gas transfer models, with potential benefits to global carbon cycle and climate modeling.  The HiWinGS results also point to persistent gaps in our fundamental understanding of air-sea gas transfer and thus provide guidance in planning future investigations.
